definition:
Let $G$ be a group under the operation $*$. The *opposite group* of $G$,
denoted $G^{\mathrm{op}}$, has the same underlying set as $G$, and its
group operation is $*'$ defined by $g_1*'g_2=g_2*g_1$.

If $G$ is abelian, then it is equal to its opposite group. Also, every
group $G$ (not necessarily abelian) is isomorphic to its opposite group:
The $\varphi \colon G \to G^{\mathrm{op}}$ is given by
$\varphi(x)=x^{-1}$. More generally, any anti-automorphism
$\psi \colon G \to G$ gives rise to a corresponding isomorphism
$\psi' \colon G \to G^{\mathrm{op}}$ via $\psi'(g)=\psi(g)$, since
$\psi'(g*h)=\psi(g*h)=\psi(h)*\psi(g)=\psi(g)*'\psi(h)=\psi'(g)*'\psi'(h)$.

Opposite groups are useful for converting a right action to a left
action and vice versa. For example, if $G$ is a group that acts on $X$
on the , then a left action of $G^{\mathrm{op}}$ on $X$ can be defined
by $g^{\mathrm{op}}x=xg$.

constructions occur in opposite ring and opposite category.
